title: How does the rate of hip and knee replacements compare internationally and over time?
analysis_commentary: Joint replacement surgery, including for hips and knees, is considered an effective intervention for severe osteoarthritis (OECD, 2013), especially for patients who have severe pain or who's mobility is affected. OECD data show that rates of both procedures have been increasing in most countries since 2000, with generally a faster increase for knee replacements. Germany carries out the most hip and knee replacements with rates per head of population approximately 76% and 38% respectively higher than those seen in the UK - even though the increase seems to have levelled off since 2008/9. UK's rate of hip replacements is very similar to rates in Australia and Italy. For knee replacements, UK has rates similar to Sweden's and Italy's. Differences in population structure and age-standardisation only explain some of the cross-country variation (OECD, 2013).
